Bright Reef School rose ahead of me, grown from a patient braid of brain coral and built-out sponges. The windows were polished abalone. A big anemone waved at the door like a pink, friendly doormat. Schools of students streamed in: a ribbon of sardines that flicked left in perfect unison, a knot of giggling clownfish trying to untangle a seaweed scarf, a quiet pair of eels who always looked like they were sharing a joke. I turned. A pufferfish hovered there, trying very hard not to puff. He had freckles, too, but you couldn’t see them until he got flustered.

“Nah,” he said, and puffed a little anyway. “I’m Pip. If you get lost, I’m good at swiveling. Also at math. But not today. Today I’m good at showing you to homeroom.” He spun like a coin and zipped toward a hallway where the jellyfish lamps hung in a line like pearl balloons. “Come on!”

Crabs with little sashes scuttled along whispering “No running, no racing, no reckless riding the currents indoors.” A cuttlefish teacher practiced changing colors in the mirror: soft purple for storytime, calm gray for tests, cheerful yellow for lunchtime. A small lanternfish drifted by, glowing just a little, and dimmed when she realized someone had noticed. I smiled at her. She lit up brighter and then zipped away, mortified.

“Homeroom’s with Mrs. Snapper,” Pip said. “She’s strict, but her smile is six teeth long.”

Mrs. Snapper was longer than six teeth across, but when she smiled, it did look like a row of pearls. Our classroom was a cozy grotto with desks made of giant clam shells. Mrs. Snapper paused, her fin hovering over the page. “That’s odd,” she murmured. “The jellies don’t falter this early.”

“Class,” she said, giving us the six-tooth smile, “there’s nothing to worry about. It seems the Central Tide Clock is off by… a beat or two. The moon-jellies sync their glow to the clock’s pulse, and they’re a little sleepy without it. Go on, Pip, lights.”

Pip floated up and tapped the little singing shells above each jelly. They hummed, and the jellies perked a bit. Not as bright as before, but better.

“What’s the Tide Clock?” I asked quietly.

Raya’s tail brushed the sand in a neat line. “It’s the heart of the city,” she whispered back. “It lives in the Plaza of Pearls. It watches the moon, holds the beat. The tides follow it, and so do we. When it’s right, the whole reef feels in rhythm, even if you can’t hear it.”

I thought about the way swimming feels when you catch the perfect current. Easy. Effortless. Like the ocean is helping.

We made it through the legend—the barnacles had terrible pitch but sang bravely anyway—and then lined up for Tide Science. Professor Inky was waiting in the lab, eight arms and a tidy bow tie, blackboard already full of diagrams. He could write with three chalks at once while erasing with another, and he hardly ever got tangled. On the ceiling above him, a model of the moon’s path spun gently, casting drifting shadows on us like clouds in slow motion.

“Class,” he said, voice low and pleasant, “today we’re talking about patterns. If you can find the pattern, you can find the problem. If you can find the problem, you can help.

“Who remembers the Tide Clock’s sequence?”

Hands, fins, and tentacles rose. Pip whispered, “Four-beat pulse, long-short-short-long.”

Professor Inky nodded, tapping the board in the rhythm. We all tapped back. Long-short-short-long. Long-short-short-long. It felt like a heartbeat shared. It felt like breathing together.

Halfway through the lesson, the whole room seemed to exhale. The model moon wobbled on its string. The jelly lamps dimmed and then brightened in a confused flutter. Somewhere far off, three drumfish boomed and then hesitated, the last beat hanging in the water like a bubble that wouldn’t pop.

Professor Inky stilled, all eight arms poised. “Hmm,” he said softly. His eyes found me, then the class. “Luminara is resilient. And curious. Curiosity is the reef’s best shield.”

When the snack bell finally chimed—late, which made everyone giggle and then look guilty—we drifted out to the courtyard. The Plaza of Pearls was only a short swim away, a round sweep of sand studded with shells and a tower of pale coral in the center. The Tide Clock lived at the top, a wheel of nacre that caught the light even on cloudy days. Today, it looked… quiet.

The lanternfish from the hall sat by herself near a cluster of seagrass rolls. I slid over with my kelp cup of plankton tea. “Hey,” I said. “I’m Tavi. Want to sit with us? We’re trying to decide if the drumfish play on purpose or because they just really like drumming.”

She smiled, a spark brightening her cheeks. “I’m Luma,” she said. “They like drumming. But mostly, they like helping little kids feel the beat.”

Pip arrived with a mouthful of sea-salt crackers and a math sheet he had somehow already finished. Raya drew a neat square in the sand so our snacks wouldn’t drift. We ate and watched the jelly lamps pulse uncertainly along the edge of the plaza. Up on the tower, a cleaner wrasse polished the clock face with serious little sweeps.

“There’s a pattern to this,” I said, the thought appearing in my head like a fish darting from a cave. “If the jellies sleep when the clock is off, and the drumfish hesitate when the beat is missing, and the tides feel… blinky, maybe the clock isn’t just watching the moon. Maybe it needs… a piece of the reef to keep it steady? Like a steadying shell.”

Luma’s glow brightened. “My aunt says the clock listens to a Pearl Bell kept in the Coral Council Chamber,” she whispered, and then looked like she shouldn’t have said it. “It’s a super old—”

A small bottle bopped my shell. I turned. It was a tiny thing, no taller than my fin, corked with a twist of kelp. Inside, a slip of paper curled like a sleeping sea slug. I pulled the cork. The note unfurled in my palm, the letters careful and looping.

To Whom It May Concern (and to anyone who loves patterns),
If you can read this, the reef is asking for listeners. The Pearl Bell hum is faint. The Clock is losing the beat. We need eyes, ears, and brave hearts the size of pebblefish. Come after last bell to the Shadowed Stair under the Plaza. Bring a friend who glows, a friend who counts, and a friend who draws maps in the sand.

— A Friend of the Beat

Pip leaned over my shoulder, eyes round. “That’s us,” he breathed. “I glow when I get nervous,” Luma said, half-apology, half-pride. Raya drew an arrow in the sand pointing toward the plaza’s underside, precise and sure. I looked at my satchel, at the corner of my reef drawing peeking out. My heart did the long-short-short-long without being asked.

Math was after snack. I like keeping promises. I like finishing chapters when the page is ready. But sometimes, a story taps you on the shell and says, Now.

“After last bell,” I said, tucking the note away. “We’ll do math. Then we’ll find the beat.”
